replies.context: A drone moving at 70-100 mph? Not likely. Maybe a shotgun at close distance but even hitting a goose at 50 yds is difficult at 100 yds near impossible.

Most enemy drones aren't constantly moving at 70-100 mph.  They have to be controlled genius by ground controllers (anything big enough to fly at altitude and be controlled by remote pilot can be taken out by missiles already).  What they are wanting to take out are drones in combat areas deployed by enemy troops.  Those drones are flying slowly and hovering (since troops can't be racing around at 70-100 mph on the battlefield).  It's an easy shot.

Sure genius. Easy shot. LOL. A drone moving at speed and at 1000 ft can easily get your position and taking out a small drone at that altitude with a missile? There's no heat signature.  LOL. Good luck taking down the most dangerous target a drone swarm armed with explosives. You're daft. Why do you think they had to buy the kind of tech in the article?

context: Does it work on ice cream filled refrigerators?

The problem with this is you can't deploy this thing in the battlefield.  It's a BIG target.  The enemy is going to blow it up.  That's why I have to wonder about some of the systems designed by military contractors sometimes.

replies.context: It's not as big as an MLRS or M109. Of course it's going to be deployed on the battlefield.

We don't deploy MLRS in the battlefield sparky.  MLRS are artillery units.  Having one sitting there in the middle of our deployed units is just silly and it would be a big win for the enemy since taking it out will create a large number of casualties for our troops.
Hey, "Sparky", MLRS is on the battlefield. We don't fight linear wars and haven't since WWII. And for reference, I'm a 25 year Field Artillery officer and combat veteran. What's your background?
27 years in the US Army and I've never seen a MLRS sitting anywhere near ground units deployed in combat sparky.
And your combat experience? If you were really in the Army for 27 years, I would think you would have learned about the non-linear battlefield, especially if you had lived it - as I have.
What do you think non-linear battlefield means exactly?  Next you'll be telling me we are parking fighter jets in ground combat zones too.

If you didn't learn that in 27 years, I can't teach it to you in this small space. The system is mounted on an LMTV - we use those as gun trucks all over the battlefield. I've been on approximately 100 combat patrols. How about you?
Now that was interesting.  Glad I quit drinking long ago.  Thank you for your service daeljuma149.

I doubt he ever served.  Can you imagine what would happen if after we trained a US Army Ranger, we then transferred them to a completely new unit 18 months later?  It just doesn't happen unless you are a major problem and your CO needs you gone.  Sounds like this guy was either a major pain or never served and has no idea what he's talking about.
I am sure he served his country well.

I'm sure.  Just be aware, he claims that the average TIG is 18 months for all officers within a unit before they are moved to a new unit.  However, that isn't the average.  That is just the minimum TIG for a First lieutenant.  It is 2 years minimum for a Captain, 3 years for a Major, 3 years for a LTC, and 3 years for a Colonel.

Man, you really are stupid. He didn't say the average time in grade (TIG) is 18 months for officers. He said the average time of assignment for officers in a position is 18 months, which is true up through battalion commander. You either just can't read, or you're really as stupid as you seem. 

He burned you. He exposed you as a fraud. Deal with it, stolen valor.
Oh really?  What was your service record?  Were you an officer?  Did you change your assigned units regularly every 18 months?  Prove me wrong.
Go ask mommy to change your diaper. We can smell you all the way over here.
That is what I thought.  I'm sick of liberals like you pretending to have served.  Talk about stolen valor.  You epitomize it.
Way to deflect. My DD214 says otherwise. You are just a miserable excuse for a human being. You're probably playing with your blowup Joe Biden doll right now.
You never had a DD214.  A real officer isn't afraid of the truth and honestly deal with questions.  Your childish insults based on ZERO facts says it all.

I've read through all of his posts and all of yours. It's obvious you're the fraud. You've been called out by numerous veterans here. And as far as the 18 months, unless you're really a slug, that's about the average time you'll spend in each position up through battalion commander, with shorter times as an LT and longer times as you move up through the ranks. My command time as a LTC was 2 years, with stellar ratings. My time as a 2LT platoon leader was a year, followed by a year as a company XO, then battalion staff. You do the math.

So, let's do the math.  I think it is instructive.  You claim your entire assignments were 2 years as a LTC + 1 year as a 2LT + 1 year as an XO and presumably 1 year as battalion staff?  So your total assignments were 5 years in total.  Correct?  You must have been amazing.  5 years of service in command and I assume you retired as an O-5?  No other service than that?

You just really have ZERO reading comprehension. My command time as a LTC was 2 years, with 3 years on brigade staff also as a LTC. That's FIVE years. XO is a position and not a grade (if you had served you would know that) and I served as a platoon leader for 1 year and a company XO for 1 year, both as a 2LT. I was promoted to 1LT and moved another XO position and then an instructor position, each for approximately 1 year. Then I became a CPT and assumed command of a company for almost 2 years, after which I moved to battalion staff for a year and then served another year and a half as an instructor (I happen to be very good at my job). I was then promoted to MAJ and spent 2 years on BN staff and another 18 months as a BN XO, then went to a BDE staff as an O4 for 2 years. Now do the math, and you'll see it averages close to 18 months in each position. If you do your job well, the Army is eager to give you new opportunities. If you do your job poorly, you tend to stay in a job for a very long time. 

You really should just stop. You're just embarrassing yourself.

Asking questions is actually important FOR reading comprehension.  I based my response on what you wrote in fact.  And the reason I'm asking you questions is to better understand your response.  I'm really getting tired of the childish insults.  But given what I think I'm dealing with, I'm not surprised.

Thank you for writing a clearer response.  And I was simply adding up assignments that you stated in your prior response.  I said nothing about XO being a rank at all which makes your snide comment just plain silly.  But that seems to be a theme with you.

So based on your answer, let me clarify some things for you.

I'm not saying that your assignments within your organizational unit don't change (they often do).  Again, that isn't the problem  My issue was "average time an officer spends in a unit is 18 months".  That is the claim that I'm stating is not true.  You don't often move from unit to unit regularly.  For example, a US Army Ranger does not typically (if ever) move from the 75th RR to the 9th Field Artillery Regiment.  Even your own service record shows that is not true.  You remained within the same organizational unit FOR YEARS by your own admission.  In fact, I'm willing to bet you were in the same Field Army for your entire service.
Johnny, you are doing just fine proving yourself wrong.

Really?  How many different Army units were you in beyond a change in platoon assignments exactly (assuming you were in the US Army)?  For example, did you even ever join a unit outside the Field Army you were in when you started your service?  I think for most in the service, that isn't usual nor does it regularly happen every 18 months at all.

And I don't expect you to answer.  I'm just tired of this nonsense and being told I'm wrong when the facts are completely on my side.

They are right..  You never served.. I am US Navy and even I can clearly read your comments and see you are full of cow pie.   AND guess what?   MRLS are on the battlefield.. Or do you think just because they are not sitting right on top of boots, that does not count?   You do realize, the enemy also has aircraft, helo's, rockets, mortars, counter battery and more .. oh wait, no you don't because you never served.. 

I hate stolen valor types like you.

Have you ever seen a MLRS launch its rockets?  What do you think would happen to ground units deployed around it?  And I don't care if you don't believe I served or not.  I did not START attacking the supposed service of this person first.  He DID.  Perhaps you didn't bother noticing that.  For the most part, I just ignored him and was pointing out how silly his claims were.  BTW - how often do they replace a Captain in the US Navy?  Every 18 months as he claims?  I think that will tell you who is speaking the truth.
Why are you so passive aggressive?

I think this guy isn't all there.  The reason we don't have MLRS in the middle of ground units engaged in combat is a MLRS is basically a mobile bomb.  One lucky shot and you'll blow up a lot of our guys fighting.  What he's saying is completely ridiculous.
OK, let me point something out to you - Call of Duty doesn't count as real-world experience. You are obviously ignorant of the basic information even a private would be expected to have in the Army.
Right.  And what unit did you serve in tulip?  I don't believe you've ever served.  But thanks for the laughs cupcake.

If you had really been in the Army, you'd know that would be a question that would take an entire page to answer for a 25 year career. However, on my right shoulder is the patch of the 20th Engineer Brigade (Airborne) as that's the unit I was attached to for my longest combat deployment. Your ignorance is overwhelming. Why don't you go play with the children and let the grownups talk?

A page full huh?  You must have been a real problem for your COs to be transferred that often?  Well, I'm not surprised since your genius plan would be to put MLRS in the middle of ground units engaged in combat.  My guess is you also were deployed in the US Air Force and proposed parking some of our airplanes in ground combat zones.  LOL

Again, you show your ignorance. The average time an officer spends in a unit is 18 months. Spread that out over 25 years and you end up with a lot of assignments. I've been in Germany, Korea, Kuwait, Iraq, and all over the US. You really should stop; the more you type, the stupider you sound - and it's getting really hard to imagine you getting any stupider (but that won't keep you from trying).
LOL Only 18 months?!?  I was mostly kidding, but wow - I didn't know how close to the truth I was.  Thanks for making my day.  Is your name LTC Vindman perhaps?

Thanks for proving my points - 1 - that you didn't serve in the Army (you would have known that officers average 18 months in an assignment); 2- that the more you type the stupider you sound.

And no, I am a LTC, but if you weren't so ignorant, you'd know that Vindman was an MI officer and I've already told you I'm an artillery officer.

So LTC Vindman, you were only a LTC for 18 months in the WH.  Strange?  Since that isn't what your bio says.  You were there a lot longer than that.  And I must have broken this rule a lot.  I was in CENTCOM for a little over 4 years.  I must have done something wrong to not be transferred as often as you.  BTW - you really have me rolling, but please continue.  Tell me all these great rules about the US Army that I never knew.  This 18 months automatic transfer to new units really made my day.
Armchair warriors substitute passive aggression for real-world experience.

context: Um, the drones they shoot are RC fighter aircraft. People love to call anything a drone these days.

replies.context: Basically, that is right.  Most civilians have no idea what they are talking about.  RC fighter aircraft is exactly what they imagine.  Battlefield drones are meant to give you eyes in the sky to assess the battlefield.  That means they are flying low over the battlefield and slowly (or hovering).  You can easily shoot them down.  A RC fighter aircraft would be moving too fast to provide good intel or be useful other than as a kamikaze.
